abstract: How did Time Inc. end up hiring an outsider — a transplant that did not take — when it once had the deepest bench in publishing?
snippet: How did Time Inc. end up hiring an outsider — a transplant that did not take — when it once had the deepest bench in publishing?
lead_paragraph: Like most bad news, the departure of Jack Griffin — the chief executive of Time Inc. for less than six months — dropped at the end of the day, leaving the publishing community scratching its head and wondering how things had gone so wrong. No one, including Mr. Griffin, saw this one coming. He was at a board meeting of Next Issue Media until 4 p.m. on Thursday, and another executive at the meeting said it was clear that Mr. Griffin did not know he was about to be fired from the world’s largest magazine publisher.

headline.main: Time Inc.: The Anatomy of a Fiasco
